articles.headline: Prevailing on Ukraine Funding, McConnell Took Political Hits
articles.snippet: The minority leader’s handling of the border and foreign aid legislation drew scorching criticism from far-right Republicans, though he scored a legislative win on an issue he regards as existential and part of his legacy.
articles.abstract: The minority leader’s handling of the border and foreign aid legislation drew scorching criticism from far-right Republicans, though he scored a legislative win on an issue he regards as existential and part of his legacy.
articles.lead_paragraph: Senator Mitch McConnell put his standing on the line in aggressively pursuing military assistance for Ukraine over deep Republican resistance, and he achieved the outcome he wanted: a strong Senate vote to bolster embattled U.S. allies at a critical moment.

articles.headline: On Capitol Hill, Republicans Use Bigoted Attacks Against Political Foes
articles.snippet: House and Senate Republicans have denigrated fellow lawmakers, Biden administration officials and witnesses in racist ways, both in casual comments and in official settings.
articles.abstract: House and Senate Republicans have denigrated fellow lawmakers, Biden administration officials and witnesses in racist ways, both in casual comments and in official settings.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Representative Marjorie Taylor Greene, Republican of Georgia, stood on the House floor this month to announce her proposal to censure the only Somali-born member of Congress, she said she was seeking punishment for “Representative Ilhan Omar of Somalia — I mean Minnesota.”

articles.headline: House Republicans Impeach Mayorkas for Border Policies
articles.snippet: In a redo of their first failed attempt, Republicans pushed through the charges over solid Democratic opposition, making the homeland security secretary the first sitting cabinet member to be impeached.
articles.abstract: In a redo of their first failed attempt, Republicans pushed through the charges over solid Democratic opposition, making the homeland security secretary the first sitting cabinet member to be impeached.
articles.lead_paragraph: The United States House of Representatives voted narrowly on Tuesday to impeach Alejandro N. Mayorkas, the homeland security secretary, in a precedent-shattering vote that charged him with willfully refusing to enforce border laws and breaching the public trust.

articles.headline: Two Students, Two Views, One Campus Conflict in the Midwest
articles.snippet: At the University of Michigan, a Palestinian activist and a self-described Zionist counterprotester have little in common, except the way they were shaped by life on campus.
articles.abstract: At the University of Michigan, a Palestinian activist and a self-described Zionist counterprotester have little in common, except the way they were shaped by life on campus.
articles.lead_paragraph: They represent opposite corners at the University of Michigan, two sides of student activism who have hunkered down and almost never communicate.

articles.headline: Wanted: True Love. Reward: $100,000.
articles.snippet: Two men posted “dating bounties” on the internet worth thousands as an incentive for people to help them find love.
articles.abstract: Two men posted “dating bounties” on the internet worth thousands as an incentive for people to help them find love.
articles.lead_paragraph: For most of Mati Roy’s life, dating was far down on his list of priorities. Though he halfheartedly tried dating apps, and would have welcomed a relationship if it developed naturally, pursuing love didn’t seem worth the effort.

articles.headline: A Feared Ex-General Appears Set to Become Indonesia’s New Leader
articles.snippet: Prabowo Subianto was ejected from the military on accusations of rights abuses. Now, he is projected to win the country’s presidency outright in the first round.
articles.abstract: Prabowo Subianto was ejected from the military on accusations of rights abuses. Now, he is projected to win the country’s presidency outright in the first round.
articles.lead_paragraph: Indonesia’s defense minister, a feared former general who was removed from the army after he was found responsible for the kidnapping of political dissidents, appeared to be on track to win the presidential election outright on Wednesday, casting doubts on the future of one of the world’s most vibrant democracies.
articles.byline: By Sui-Lee Wee and Muktita Suhartono

articles.headline: Can America Turn a Productivity Boomlet Into a Boom?
articles.snippet: After drooping in 2022, the output of U.S. businesses per worker has surged. Economists wonder if the trend can continue, and who will benefit most.
articles.abstract: After drooping in 2022, the output of U.S. businesses per worker has surged. Economists wonder if the trend can continue, and who will benefit most.
articles.lead_paragraph: Kevin Rezvani came of age in kitchens: spending summers at his grandfather’s bakery in Japan, doing work-study in his college cafeteria and working for years as a line cook at mid-tier restaurants, along with some stints in fast food.

articles.headline: Three Lessons From a Surprisingly Resilient Job Market
articles.snippet: The recovery from the pandemic lockdowns has prompted economists to consider whether their playbook is outdated or just missing a page.
articles.abstract: The recovery from the pandemic lockdowns has prompted economists to consider whether their playbook is outdated or just missing a page.
articles.lead_paragraph: The pandemic created an economic crisis unlike any recession on record. So perhaps it shouldn’t be surprising that the aftermath, too, has played out in a way that almost no economists expected.
